@svs It wasn't a bad decision, but it put then in the wrong position. You can't half-dodge an oncoming train, they needed more action.
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy so many things about that case and judgement I don’t understand as a layman.
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy the suggestions were consistent tho - [21] (c) intent, (d) harm to ordinary person, but not (e) harm to her?
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy of course, and perhaps she is more resilient than the objective person (who was found to be harmed), still seems weird.
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy [74] seems to be the key to it, and I presume is why they’re appealing so they can fix it.
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy so I see, and they were light on testimony too. Feels like a prosecution screwup?
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy was the evidence her actions, or the judgement of a psychologist?
@djhdcj @NZPrivacy The article implied that the judge felt it didn’t, based on the womans actions after. Feels like a lot of wiggle room?
